qas.question: What decade marked the peak of support for opposition to New Zealand's governance?
What was the name of the Mau leader who was of Samoan and Swedish descent?
What philosophy characterized the Mau resistance?
What title was given to the Mau's elected leader, Tupua Tamasese Lealofi?
On what date did the Mau demonstrate on the streets of Apia?

plausible_answers.text: inflation and the catastrophic 1918 flu epidemic

qas.question: What events did New Zeland hold Samoa responsible for?
What was lead by Olaf Frederick Nelson on December 28, 1929?
Where did Olaf Fredrick Nelson organize and lead the demonstration?
What did High Chief Tupua Tamasese Lealofi resent?
What was the philosophy of most New Zelanders?

context: However, Samoans greatly resented <b8_0>New Zealand's colonial rule<b8_0/>, and blamed <b5_0>inflation and the catastrophic 1918 flu epidemic<b5_0/> on its misrule. By the late <a0_0>1920s<a0_0/> the resistance movement against colonial rule had gathered widespread support. One of the Mau leaders was <a1_0>Olaf Frederick Nelson<a1_0/>, a half Samoan and half Swedish merchant. Nelson was eventually exiled during the late 1920s and early 1930s, but he continued to assist the organisation financially and politically. In accordance with the Mau's <a2_0><b9_0>non-violent<b9_0/> philosophy<a2_0/>, the newly elected leader, <a3_0>High Chief<a3_0/> Tupua Tamasese Lealofi, led his fellow uniformed Mau in <b6_0>a peaceful demonstration<b6_0/> <b7_0>in downtown Apia<b7_0/> on <a4_0>28 December 1929<a4_0/>.
